instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL6529: What is ISL6529? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.D6990: What is D6990? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input, can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.R6990: What is R6990? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on Macbooks from around the year 2012. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H: What is PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H? PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H is the input voltage to the PP3V42_G3H buck converter circuit, it can be either charger voltage or battery voltage depending on what the system power source is. This often shorts to ground when one of the input capacitors dies. .
definitions.C6990: What is C6990? Capacitor to ground on input to PP3V42_G3H power supply. PP3V42_G3H power supply turns 18.5v from charger or 8.5v-12.5v PPBUS_G3H from the battery into PP3V42_G3H. This capacitor can short to ground and keep PP3V42_G3H from turning on which would keep the machine from having a light on the magsafe charger.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.PP3V42_G3H_REG: What is PP3V42_G3H_REG? PP3V42_G3H_REG is another way to say PP3V42_G3H. PP3V42_G3H_REG and PP3V42_G3H are a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.P3V42_G3H: What is P3V42_G3H? P3V42_G3H is a typo of PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA is the data line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL: What is SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL? SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL is the clock line of an I2C data line between the battery charging chip that creates PPBUS_G3H, the system management controller(SMC), the battery, and the battery indicator LED. If this line’s resistance to ground is too low because of a defective component, battery will not be recognized with an X on the icon and PPBUS_G3H voltage will be lower than it is on a good system..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had no water damage. It had no GREEN LIGHT

Power Rails were:
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>  0.0V  - NO SHORT
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>   0.0V - NO SHORT

Found SHORT on:
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> @ <CAPACITOR>C7031</CAPACITOR> + <CAPACITOR>C7030</CAPACITOR> (22UF) -top of cap read: 22 1E24
 I have a donor board and replaced those caps and got rid of the SHORT
The DONOR CAPS read on top:  22 1E2N (ORIGINALS WERE 22 1E24)
Does that make a difference?

I replaced <CHIP>ISL6529</CHIP> -<CHIP>U7000</CHIP> with new chip. I'm now reading and I think I might have needed to replace 2 or 3 other components at the same time before giving it power?

TESTED VOLTAGE AFTER AND STILL:

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>  0.0V  - NO SHORT
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>   0.0V - NO SHORT
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> 0.2V - NO SHORT

Any advice going forward is much appreciated.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I didn't see the reason for changing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> yet.

You may have an input leakage issue, as you don't get any voltage on the board.
Check first if F6905 is good and has voltage.

F6905 has continuity between PIN 1 & Pin 2

Voltage with 85w charger connected

PIN 1 = 0.0V
PIN 2 = 0.0V

DIODE MODE

PIN1 = .OL
PIN 2= .OL

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Well I just realized I was getting Trolled by my power strip.  It had disabled only one plug. My charger.
When I connected it with "POWER" this time I saw a GREEN LIGHT but also smoke around <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>
With freeze spray <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> (PIN 1 =<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>/ PIN 2=<SIGNAL>P18V5_DCIN_CONN_R</SIGNAL>)
looks hot right away.

Took off <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> on the Pads I get:
Voltage: PIN 1 = 16.77V PIN2= -0.05V
DIODE MODE: PIN1= 1.97 PIN2= 0.0

I just changed the DC in board as I think it was part of the culprit too and it was.  Facepalm.
If I replace <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> I'm worried that I'll "Smoke Check" something again.
Should I be concerned with <DIODE>D6990</DIODE>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Really strange to get short in pin 2/<RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>.
In such case, (at least) lower side of <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> is also shorted.
You must replace both R/<DIODE>D6990</DIODE>.
Do not apply power yet; you will still have short on <SIGNAL>PPVIN_G3H_P3V42G3H</SIGNAL>.
Remove <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR> and check if short went off.
If still present, change <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
After that check again for short at <CAPACITOR>C6990</CAPACITOR>/99; before applying power on the board.

Diode mode on <DIODE>D6990</DIODE> PIN 1=0.45 - PIN 2= 1.98 PIN 3= 0.34

Not too sure if there was still a short so just replaced <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>

Added power no green light (no smoke either)

Now <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> PIN 1=16.7 PIN 2= 16.7

<CHIP>U6990</CHIP> VOLTAGE

PIN 4= 16.45v  
PIN 3= 15v
PIN 2= 3.8v
PIN 1=1.2v

PIN 10= 3.2v
PIN 9= 3.4v (<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>).
PIN 8= 3.4v
PIN 7= 16.45v
PIN 6= 3.4v

<DIODE>D6690</DIODE> Voltage
PIN 1= 0.399v  (is this the problem?) <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H_R</SIGNAL>
PIN 2 = 16.7v
PIN 3= 16.45v


<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 0.277v   @ F7040
Diode Mode 0.477 @ F7040  

Thx again. this ones kicking my butt

Board doesn't turn on?

For green light issue, post <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> voltages.
Check continuity from pin 5 of <CHIP>U6900</CHIP> to central pin of Magsafe (DCIN board).

I'll measure <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> it will be one thing, disconnect the power supply and connect again and it's another. Once I plug and plug back in it starts to produce the right voltage? I'll try another charger or switch power strips. I'm not doing anything wierd to the board and my Soldering skills are good I would think. I've been successful with iPhone IC and Macbook SMC's just saying so that your not wondering if I'm a newb to SMD work, I'm not.   I just going off what I'm experiencing don't know if this is possible or not. Maybe my power strip is going bad.. So I get 0.048 PIN 14 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and <CHIP>U6901</CHIP> has <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> if 0.045 is high.

It would seem I have the right voltages unless <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is not high enough. Just have to figure out where my <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> went

Diode mode 19/20 = 0.003 both
Voltage Pin 19/20 =0.383v both

Not too sure if a Capacitor can go to ground on both ends I know an iPhone CPU cap can but I thought I'd mention right around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> that <CAPACITOR>C7001</CAPACITOR> Pin 1 (<SIGNAL>PP5V1_CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL>) has path to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Just posting info because I had lost some rails and I'm a newb on diagnosis of Macbook boards...:cautious: So just wanted to give you the updated info after replacing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Just wanted to be thorough.
The last post was after replacing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
And the short on c700/1 went away. Also <CAPACITOR>C7005</CAPACITOR> is not getting hot quick. And all of the voltages in the last post are current.

threads.message:
So now you have 12.2V at <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.
Check <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and diode mode to ground at SCL/SDA lines of battery bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> =  0.043v  - Diode mode = 0.431

J6950 Diode mode

Pin 4 = 0.499 (<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>)
Pin 5 = 0.499 (<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL>)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>

J6950 Diode mode

Pin 4 = 0.499 (<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL</SIGNAL>)
Pin 5 = 0.499 (<SIGNAL>SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA</SIGNAL>) 

Acutually I'm not too sure where to measure <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

So here goes:

<CHIP>U5010</CHIP>
Pin 5 = 3.44v

<RESISTOR>R7000</RESISTOR>
PIN 1 = 3.44V

The test point in the attached picture = 0.0v

threads.message:
I'll post a couple spots as I'm not confident where I should be testing but if you tell me once I'll remember.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> @
<RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> = 12.23v

F7040 = 12.22 PIN 1/2

<RESISTOR>R4264</RESISTOR> = 12.24
<TRANSISTOR>Q4262</TRANSISTOR> = 12.24 Pin 4
F9700 = 12.24

<CAPACITOR>C3338</CAPACITOR> = 12.24
<RESISTOR>R3880</RESISTOR> = 12.24
<TRANSISTOR>Q5480</TRANSISTOR> = 12.23
<RESISTOR>R5481</RESISTOR> = 12.23

<TRANSISTOR>Q4260</TRANSISTOR> = 12.23
<CAPACITOR>C4260</CAPACITOR> = 12.24
<RESISTOR>R4260</RESISTOR> = 12.24

<RESISTOR>R5410</RESISTOR> = 12.24

I hope that's not too overkill.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Be sure to use original Magsafe 60/85W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Using Original 85w charger

<SIGNAL>PM_BAT_LOW_L</SIGNAL> = 0.008V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
PCH will not start then.

<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is low?

Check for corrosion around SMC.
Pay atention to L4901, <RESISTOR>R4902</RESISTOR>, Y/R/<CAPACITOR>C5010</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5011</CAPACITOR>.

Check voltage for <SIGNAL>1V2_S5_SMC</SIGNAL> and the 4 <SIGNAL>SMC_TXX</SIGNAL> lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Did a reading on <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> after looking though forum. Not sure if this will help.

Pins 1-12 = 0.0v
Pin 16 = 12.42v

Just one more note. At some point during this repair the green light went on and then I saw smoke from <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR>.  I replaced bad caps and <RESISTOR>R6990</RESISTOR> and everything else you helped me with. Not sure if that would burn out a trace but just thought I'd mention it.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No green light -short on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>

0.60v @ <CHIP>U7941</CHIP>


No corrosion around SMC or anywhere on board.

[B]<CAPACITOR>C5011</CAPACITOR> [/B]= [COLOR=rgb(209, 72, 65)][B]-0.030  this reading just changed  to 0.0v[/B][/COLOR]
[B]Y5010[/B] PIN 1 = 0.303V PINS 2-4 =  0.0V
